Award.AbstractNarration:
Under this grant, the PI will work on problems related to surfaces in 3-manifolds. The virtual Haken conjecture asks whether any aspherical closed 3-manifold has a finite-sheeted cover which contains a closed surface which injects on the fundamental group. The PI proposes to work on this conjecture making use of recent results of Kahn-Markovic and Wise. This would have ramifications for related conjectures, such as the virtual fibering conjecture, and would greatly elucidate the structure of 3-manifolds and their invariants, such as twisted Alexander polynomials. The PI also proposes to study the Thurston norm, and the relation between various surfaces realizing the Thurston norm in a minimal homology class via sutured manifold hierarchies. He hopes to use these relations to study various questions about the Thurston norm and its relation to other invariants of the 3-manifold.

The mathematical study of 3-dimensional spaces goes back to the work of Poincare. Because classical physics describes our universe to be a 3-dimensional space, the classification of 3-dimensional spaces is an important mathematical endeavor, since it may have ramifications for the global structure of our universe. This project will pursue various aspects of the classification of 3-dimensional spaces. The principal and most ambitious project will study 2-dimensional objects inside of 3-dimensional spaces, and how one may resolve these in related "covering spaces". Studying these 2-dimensional objects has implications for the global structure of finite 3-dimensional spaces. The techniques of the project will have relations to other areas of mathematics such as group theory, geometry, and the study of 4-dimensional spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated 3-dimensional spaces, called 3-dimensional manifolds. The best understood such spaces are called Haken 3-manifolds, which contain a 2-dimensional subspace of a special type, called an "incompressible surface". In 1968, Waldhausen formulated a question as to which 3-dimensional manifolds have a finite-sheeted cover (a related manifold with a finite-to-one map to the original one) which is Haken. We answered this question during this period of NSF support. The answer relies on results of Kahn and Markovic and Wise, in addition to the geometrization conjecture proved by Perelman. Part of the work is joint with Groves and Manning. The techniques used to prove this conjecture are word-hyperbolic groups and CAT(0) cube complexes,  notions introduced by Gromov in the 1980s. A related question (for hyperbolic 3-manifolds, those which admit a metric of negative curvature) which was resolved is Thurston's virtual fibering conjecture. A remarkable feature of the proof is that to answer questions about 3-dimensional spaces, one had to consider high-dimensional spaces made out of hypercubes, and admitting a coarse form of negative curvature. Dani Wise formulated a conjecture about these spaces which we resolved using his techniques (the virtual special malnormal quotient theorem). Recently Groves, Manning and I gave a new proof of this result following the strategy of Wise's proof, but replacing cubical small-cancellation theory with relatively hyperbolic Dehn filling developed by Groves-Manning and Osin. The proof still relies on joint work of Wise with Haglund and Hsu. The conjecture was formulated by Wise in broad enough generality that certain inductive arguments could be made which aren't possible in the category of 3-dimensional spaces. However, many techniques of the proof originated in the study of 3-dimensional hyperbolic manifolds, including Haken hierarchies, hyperbolic Dehn filling, and geometric finiteness, which have analogues in the context of cube complexes with hyperbolic fundamental group. Intuition developed in the context of 3-dimensional manifolds could be brought to bear in this more general context. The fact that 3-dimensional hyperbolic manifolds fall into this category is due to Bergeron and Wise relying on Kahn and Markovic's proof of the existence of nearly geodesic surfaces in hyperbolic 3-manifolds. 

In unrelated work, together with Coda-Marques and Neves, we proved that the Möbius energy of non-split 2-component links is minimized for the standard Hopf link, with a value of 2π^2. This was conjectured by Freedman-He-Wang in the 90s. The Gauss map of the 2-component link gives a lower bound on the Möbius energy which is not sharp. But stereographically projecting the link to 4-dimensions, one also obtains a lower bound on the Möbius energy from the area of the Gauss map in the 3-sphere. Such projections form a 4-dimensional space, and one can get a 5-dimensional space by moving the two components to different planes. The resulting 5-dimenisonal space of tori in the 3-sphere gives a non-trivial sweepout to which the technology developed by Coda-Marques and Neves in the resolution of the Willmore conjecture may be applied, and one sees by a minimax argument that the maximal area of tori must be at least 2π^2, giving the desired lower bound. The optimal case is when the torus is the Clifford torus, and the corresponding link is the standard Hopf link consiting of two orthogonal planes in 4-space intersecting the unit 3-sphere.
